name: Logger
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger
description:
Logger

An API-compatible replacement for ruby’s Logger that logs to the Stackdriver Logging Service.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/logging"

logging = Google::Cloud::Logging.new

resource = logging.resource "gae_app",
                            module_id: "1",
                            version_id: "20150925t173233"

logger = logging.logger "my_app_log", resource, env: :production
logger.info "Job started."

methods.name: writer
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#writer
methods.description: The Google Cloud writer object that calls to #write_entries are made on. Either an AsyncWriter or Project object.

methods.name: log_name
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#log_name
methods.description: The Google Cloud log_name to write the log entry with.

methods.name: resource
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#resource
methods.description: The Google Cloud resource to write the log entry with.

methods.name: labels
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#labels
methods.description: The Google Cloud labels to write the log entry with.

methods.name: level
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#level
methods.description: The logging severity threshold (e.g. Logger::INFO)

methods.name: formatter
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#formatter
methods.description: This logger does not use a formatter, but it provides a default Logger::Formatter for API compatibility with the standard Logger.

methods.name: formatter=
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#formatter=
methods.description: This logger does not use a formatter, but it provides a default Logger::Formatter for API compatibility with the standard Logger.

methods.name: datetime_format
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#datetime_format
methods.description: This logger does not use a formatter, but it implements this attribute for API compatibility with the standard Logger.

methods.name: datetime_format=
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#datetime_format=
methods.description: This logger does not use a formatter, but it implements this attribute for API compatibility with the standard Logger.

methods.name: progname=
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#progname=
methods.description: This logger treats progname as an alias for log_name.

methods.name: trace_ids
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#trace_ids
methods.description: A OrderedHash of Thread IDs to Stackdriver request trace ID. The Stackdriver trace ID is a shared request identifier across all Stackdriver services.

methods.name: initialize
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#initialize
methods.description: Create a new Logger instance.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/logging"

logging = Google::Cloud::Logging.new

writer = logging.async_writer max_queue_size: 1000

resource = logging.resource "gae_app", labels: {
                              "module_id" => "1",
                              "version_id" => "20150925t173233"
                            }

logger = Google::Cloud::Logging::Logger.new writer,
                                            "my_app_log",
                                            resource,
                                            env: :production
logger.info "Job started."

params.name: writer
params.description:
The object that will transmit log
entries. Generally, to create a logger that blocks on transmitting
log entries, pass the Project; otherwise, to create a logger that
transmits log entries in the background, pass an AsyncWriter. You
may also pass any other object that responds to #write_entries.

params.name: log_name
params.description:
A log resource name to be associated with the
written log entries.

params.name: resource
params.description:
The monitored
resource to be associated with written log entries.

params.name: labels
params.description:
A set of user-defined data to be associated with
written log entries.

returns.description:
a Logger object that can be
used in place of a ruby standard library logger object.

methods.name: debug
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#debug
methods.description: Log a DEBUG entry.

params.name: message
params.description:
The log entry payload, represented as
either a string, a hash (JSON), or a hash (protocol buffer).

params.name: yield
params.description:
Evaluates to the message to log. This is not evaluated unless
the logger’s level is sufficient to log the message. This allows you
to create potentially expensive logging messages that are only
called when the logger is configured to show them.

title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#info
methods.description: Log an INFO entry.

params.name: message
params.description:
The log entry payload, represented as
either a string, a hash (JSON), or a hash (protocol buffer).

params.name: yield
params.description:
Evaluates to the message to log. This is not evaluated unless
the logger’s level is sufficient to log the message. This allows you
to create potentially expensive logging messages that are only
called when the logger is configured to show them.

methods.name: unknown
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#unknown
methods.description: Log an UNKNOWN entry. This will be printed no matter what the logger’s current severity level is.

params.name: message
params.description:
The log entry payload, represented as
either a string, a hash (JSON), or a hash (protocol buffer).

params.name: yield
params.description:
Evaluates to the message to log. This is not evaluated unless
the logger’s level is sufficient to log the message. This allows you
to create potentially expensive logging messages that are only
called when the logger is configured to show them.

methods.name: add
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#add
methods.description: Log a message if the given severity is high enough. This is the generic logging method. Users will be more inclined to use #debug, #info, #warn, #error, and #fatal.

params.name: severity
params.description:
the integer code for or the
name of the severity level

params.name: message
params.description:
The log entry payload, represented as
either a string, a hash (JSON), or a hash (protocol buffer).

params.name: yield
params.description:
Evaluates to the message to log. This is not evaluated unless
the logger’s level is sufficient to log the message. This allows you
to create potentially expensive logging messages that are only
called when the logger is configured to show them.

title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#<<
methods.description: Logs the given message at UNKNOWN severity.

params.name: msg
params.description: The log entry payload as a string.

methods.name: debug?
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#debug?
methods.description: Returns true if the current severity level allows for sending DEBUG messages.

methods.name: info?
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#info?
methods.description: Returns true if the current severity level allows for sending INFO messages.

methods.name: warn?
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#warn?
methods.description: Returns true if the current severity level allows for sending WARN messages.

methods.name: error?
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#error?
methods.description: Returns true if the current severity level allows for sending ERROR messages.

methods.name: fatal?
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#fatal?
methods.description: Returns true if the current severity level allows for sending FATAL messages.

methods.name: level=
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#level=
methods.description: Sets the logging severity level.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/logging"

logging = Google::Cloud::Logging.new

resource = logging.resource "gae_app",
                            module_id: "1",
                            version_id: "20150925t173233"

logger = logging.logger "my_app_log", resource, env: :production

logger.level = "INFO"
logger.debug "Job started." # No log entry written

params.name: severity
params.description:
the integer code for or the
name of the severity level

methods.name: close
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#close
methods.description: Close the logging “device”. This effectively disables logging from this logger; any further log messages will be silently ignored. The logger may be re-enabled by calling #reopen.

methods.name: reopen
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#reopen
methods.description:
Re-enable logging if the logger has been closed.

Note that this method accepts a “logdev” argument for compatibility with the standard Ruby Logger class; however, this argument is ignored because this logger does not use a log device.

methods.name: add_trace_id
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#add_trace_id
methods.description: Track a given trace_id by associating it with the current Thread

methods.name: add_request_info
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#add_request_info
methods.description: Associate request data with the current Thread. You may provide either the individual pieces of data (trace ID, log name) or a populated RequestInfo object.

params.name: info
params.description:
Info about the current request. Optional.
If not present, a new RequestInfo is created using the remaining
parameters.

params.name: trace_id
params.description: The trace ID, or nil if no trace ID should be logged.

params.name: log_name
params.description:
The log name to use, or nil to use
this logger’s default.

methods.name: request_info
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#request_info
methods.description: Get the request data for the current Thread

returns.description: The request data for the current thread, or nil if there is no data set.

methods.name: delete_request_info
title: Google
Cloud
Logging
Logger#delete_request_info
methods.description: Untrack the RequestInfo that’s associated with current Thread
